core – Core AD Functionality¶

Core functionality behind the active_directory2 functionality. The functions in this module either return strings or Python COM objects representing the underlying ADSI COM objects. These will be wrapped by ADBase and other modules to give extended functionality, but they can be useful on their own.

The functions in this module are built upon by all the other modules, but can sensibly be used in their own right by users of the active_directory2 package. For efficiency, most of them cache their results so that, eg, a lookup for an attribute’s schema doesn’t need to bind to the directory every time. (Although the bind itself should be cached by AD behind the scenes).

Return the first attribute corresponding to name from attributes().

Parameters:
  • name – The name of an attribute whose data is to be returned
  • server – A specific server whose rootDSE is to be found [None - any server]
  • cred – anything accepted by credentials.credentials()
Returns:

name, info per attributes() for the named attribute

An iteration of (name, info)

active_directory2.core.open_object(moniker, cred=None, flags=0)¶

Open an AD object represented by moniker, optionally authenticated. You will not normally call this yourself: it is used internally by the AD objects.

Parameters:
  • moniker – A complete AD moniker representing an AD object
  • cred – anything accepted by credentials.credentials()
  • flags – optional constants.AUTHENTICATION_TYPES flags. The credentials will set the appropriate flags for authentication, and server binding will be used if the moniker is server-based.
Returns:

a COM object corresponding to moniker and authenticated according to cred

This function is at the heart of authenticated access to AD offered by this package. The credentials work as follows:

  • cred is passed to credentials.credentials() for initial processing
  • If cred is now a credentials.Credentials object, this is used for authentication
  • Otherwise moniker is parsed to determine the (optional) server name and the cache is checked for corresponding credentials.
  • If no cached credentials are found, passthrough authentication is assumed.

This will normally do what you expect. The default (passthrough) is far and away the most common. Specific credentials can either be passed in, eg, as a tuple, or can be held in the credentials cache and inferred from the server:

from active_directory2 import core, credentials

me = core.open_object ("LDAP://cn=Tim Golden,dc=goldent,dc=local")
me = core.open_object ("LDAP://cn=Tim Golden,dc=goldent,dc=local", cred=("goldent\\tim", "pa55w0rd"))
with credentials.credentials (("goldent\\tim", "5ecret", "testing")):
  me = core.open_object (core.root_moniker ())
me = core.open_object ("LDAP://testing/dc=test,dc=local", cred=credentials.Anonymous)
active_directory2.core.query(obj, filter, attributes=None, flags=<Unset>)¶

Run an LDAP query specified by filter against the AD object obj. This query is at the heart of the search functionality in this package. It can be called directly either from this module or from any of the higher-level AD objects such as adbase.ADBase which expose it as a method.

The result is an iteration of dictionaries mapping attribute names to a list of values. No attempt is made here to determine which values are single and which are multivalued.

Typical usage:

Parameters:
  • obj – An ADSI object which implements the IDirectorySearch interface
  • filter – A valid ADSI/LDAP filter string
  • attributes – A list of attributes (AD fields) to return. None => All
  • flags – A combination of constants.ADS_SEARCHPREF values
Returns:

iterator over a dictionary mapping attribute names to lists of values

Returns:

The COM Object corresponding to the RootDSE for the server or domain
